OTTAWA.

Re: St. Cyprian & Sacred Heart Indian Residential Schools, Peigan Agency.
Your files 116-1-5(2) of August 20 and 116-2-5(3) of May 7th.

When your letter of May 7th was received, we made inquiries about the buildings mentioned therein but were informed that they were frozen. Shortly afterwards Mr. Ruddick of the Donald Inspection Company, Montreal, made an inspection of the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School and though we have no copy of his report as yet, he has informed us that he is definitely recommending that there be no further expenditure on new buildings at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School. Also no further action was taken pending outcome of our plan to provide extra classroom blocks at the Blood Agency.

We have since been informed by the Provincial Laboratory, University of Alberta, that the water being obtained from the spring at the Sacred Heart School contains marked evidence of unfavorable bacterial contamination. Mr. McMillan has been instructed to inform the principal of the school that boiling of the water must be resorted to, to insure safety where used for domestic purposes.

However, we have written to War Assets, Calgary and a copy of our letter is attached. When a reply is received, you will be further advised.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Enc.
B. F. Neary, Esq.,
Superintendent of Education,

We have since been informed by the Provincial Laboratory, University of Alberta, that the water being obtained from the spring at the Sacred Heart School contains marked evidence of unfavorable bacterial contamination. Mr. McMillan has been instructed to inform the principal of the school that boiling of the water must be resorted to, to insure safety where used for domestic purposes.

However, we have written to War Assets, Calgary and a copy of our letter is attached. When a reply is received, you will be further advised.

G. H. Gooderham,

RFB/MG

1. We named three buildings outstanding to use two only for St. Cyprian's, the other for Sacred Heart.
2. Ruddick's reasons are not yet known.
3. $50 to repair Red Jacket pump has been authorized; maybe he will dig the deep well.
4. Could we now start asking what the various sources of water are and how much she gets from each source and the costs thereof?

We are in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, file 116-10-8, with reference to the St. Cyprian and Sacred Heart Residential Schools.

It is noted that you have again written to the War Assets Corporation, Calgary, with regard to the buildings which it was proposed to obtain for use at the two residential schools mentioned above. We have not yet received a report from the Donald Inspection Limited on these schools.

We have already authorized the repair of the jacket pump at a cost of $50.00 but in order that our file may be complete, we would like to know the various sources from which the principal of the Sacred Heart school obtained water, and the approximate amount of water he obtains daily from each source.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Sacred Heart Indian Residential School.

Attached please find account amounting to $213.12 covering the cost of repairs to the Lister Bruston Engine at the above mentioned school.

It was necessary to have this engine repaired immediately in order that the school might function properly.

Please issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows: 516-759-09-615.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

EFN/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources Ottawa.

Attention Mr Neary,

I have received a letter from The Regional Supervisor re the approximate amount of water received from each source at the Sacred Heart School, as per letter of Sept 11th 1948.

I apparently did not receive this letter, however I have contacted the new Principal, and also from my own knowledge would state that previous to the Spring rains that 75% was hauled from the C,P,R water tank, and the balance from the Spring.

After the heavy rainfall till the end of June, the approximate percentage was almost the same the other way with the late principal filling the Reservoir, from the Tank and the Spring keeping it up with the odd hauling.

It would seem that this hauling from the water tank will have to be started regularly as soon as the spring and well weaken, and the question that arises from this would be should I be vouchering monthly for the assistance for hauling water, when there is a very small amount hauled. I am holding the November bill until I hear from you.

Superintendent.

Copy to Mr Gooderham.
December 22, 1948.

Mr. Anthony McMillan,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Brocket, Alberta.

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to payments for hauling water to the Sacred Heart School, if the only duty required of the member of the staff is hauling water, it is felt that the payment should be made monthly, even though the amount of water hauled some months is less than others. On the other hand, if the hauling of water is done in the spare time of some member of the staff who has other duties, it is felt that you could make arrangements with the principal that would be satisfactory to all parties concerned.

Possibly during those months that it is only necessary to haul a small amount of water it would be advisable to forward the usual voucher every second month instead of every month.

Please discuss the matter with the principal and let us hear from you again.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

I am in receipt of a very pressing letter from the principal of the above school, Reverend Father Forestier, O.M.I., in which he requests the purchase of a Massey Harris snowplow no 44, to keep the road from the school to the village clear of snow during the Winter months.

This school as you know is five miles from the village and away from all stores and conveniences. It is true that the school has been doing without this snowplow since it was built, but we did live years ago without telephone, telegraph, automobiles or trucks and still no one complains when money is now expended to procure such facilities and conveniences.

Re Fire - Sacred Heart School.

On the evening of Saturday 19th February, I was contacted by Telephone to advise me that there was a fire in the corridor between the second and third floor, I immediately approached the head of the Armories re an Army truck, and also the Pincher Creek Fire Brigade, who promised to be ready immediately I received any worse news. In fifteen minutes I received a call that it was under control, and advised them to call me if it got worse, it started up again in the wall about 2 A.M. but was handled immediately, and instructed the principal to put extra guards on. I phoned Sunday and found everything o.K., so asked Father Perrestier to have the Jeep available Monday at 9 O'clock, I went out to the school, and looked over the situation, but was unable to find anything as to where it would start, I returned to the Agency and called you, and after received your instructions, phoned the Stockton & Day Electric at Macleod, and arranged for an inspection on Tuesday morning, he arrived and went out in the Jeep, and spent all morning there and checked all the wiring close to the fire and found everything all right.

He however found a nest which he thought might be a mouse and a large number of matches, and a piece of string, and a trinket, which he brought to the Office and left with me, I showed to one or two parties who I thought might know and I got the impression from these men that it might have been a pack rat. I am sending in another envelope enclosed with this letter the articles which were taken out of the place where the fire occurred.

Mr Stockton is giving me his report on Thursday when I will forward it to you with further comments, the children are out, returning on the 6th March, and I am leaving the opening cut during the fire open so that it may dry up before repairing it.

I would like to receive authority from Ottawa to return the children to school on the 6th, if no further fire happens, and also would recommend that in the schools the Night Watchman who is on till April be authorized to stay till the end of the school term.

I would also like to commend Charles Provost Sr for the way he handled his job in locating the fire and awakening the school.

Dear Sir:

Saturday night, Feb. 19 at 11:00 A.M. a fire broke out at
the Sacred Heart School; lucky the night watchman was on the
alert; he was going for his round at that time and he smelt
smoke on the first floor between the chapel and the Principal's
room; he continued making his round and came back and still
smelt smoke; he took his flash light and saw smoke coming
through the ceiling, between the sewer pipe and the tin.

Charlie Provost who was night watchman woke Brother Albert
up and Tharcis Forestier, employed at the school, heard Charlie
Provost talking, he got up and told Charlie to wake the
children up, which he did immediately. The children woke up
and came out without any panic.

Tharcis Forestier, Brother Albert and George Schultz the
farmer went to work with the axes and the fire extinguishers;
they worked for three hours steady and came to control the
fire; they went downstairs for a lunch and at 3:00 A.M. the
fire started once more, they went to work again for three
hours steady and got the fire under control with the auto-
matic fire extinguishers which I have bought in November,
and which saved the building; I had asked the Dept. to
supply these fire extinguishers and they turned me down.

The roads being impassable, nobody could come to our help
and that night it was 10° below zero weather, we had to send
the children in the barn while they were fighting the fire.
Mr. A. MacMillan came Monday morning to examine the situation, and decided to send the children home for ten days, which I think was wise, and he also wired Mr. Gooderham in Calgary to send an expert electrician to examine the situation. This expert as well as Mr. MacMillan told me that it was not caused by electricity, that everything was in perfect condition; all during the fire the lights stayed on, if there would have been a short circuit some lights would have been out.

Mr. Stooton, the electrician, examined over and over again and where the fire started he found a mice nest and also fifteen matches, so came to the conclusion that the fire might have been started in that way in the mice nest, he could not find any other cause how it could possibly start.

We have to give credit to our good night watchman Mr. Charlie Provost who located the fire first and also the other three men employed for the school, who worked like fifteen men to get the fire under control; I was surely glad to have bought those automatic fire extinguishers which saved the building.

Would it be possible to have a night watchman year round because that fire goes to prove that the fire could also start in the summer time as well; the cause of fire is not always started by fire, but from unknown causes. I think it is very important to have a night watchman all the time especially in a building which is not fireproof. I would appreciate that very much, especially for saving lives of so many people.

If the night watchman would have come there ten minutes later, it would have been too late to stop the fire and probably the lives of 85 people; I think it is a very serious matter.

Would it be possible for the Dept. to renew my automatic fire extinguishers without any delay; really I feel bad now that the Dept. have turned me down; and when I think that is the only thing that saved us, I would appreciate very much if my demand was granted as soon as possible, especially for the safeguard of the Indian Children and the Staff and for the parents of the children who are scared to send their children back to school unless we get a night watchman year round, and also the automatic fire extinguishers.

I remain,

Yours truly

[Signature]
Principal

Memorandum re Water Supply, Sacred Heart Indian Residential School
Brocket, Alberta

Examined March 21, 1949

This residential school for Indian children mainly from the Pigeon Indian Reservation in Southern Alberta, is located five miles east of the railroad hamlet of Brocket, Alberta. At present there is a staff of fifteen and an enrollment of sixty-eight students. It is operated by the Roman Catholic Church, with assistance from the Dominion Government.

Water is supplied from a spring 200 yards east of the barn and 250 yards from the school. A manhole covered the spring at the time of the examination but it is said to be a concrete reservoir 6 x 6 x 9 feet high with a 2-foot square manhole extending 5 feet upward and rising 9 inches above the ground. Two underground wings on either side of the reservoir deflect the water into the reservoir. The manhole has a tin cover which is always kept in place. The water is pumped from the reservoir by a 500 gallon-per-minute Red Jacket pump to two pressure tanks each of 1200 gallons.

The samples of water taken for bacteriological analysis showed the presence of B. coli as indicated by the attached form. The spring is located in a field near the barn and cattle and horses have free access to the immediate area. Fecal matter of these animals could find its way through the soil into the spring, thus causing the B. coli in the samples taken for analysis, although this seems quite unlikely in the winter when the ground is frozen and the immediate area of the spring is covered with snow. However, no other source appears to be the cause.

The attached chemical analysis indicates the water to be of good chemical quality although it is quite hard. The nitrate nitrogen content (0.41%) indicates the presence of stabilized organic matter, possibly derived from sewage.

Conclusions and Recommendations

The water at this Indian residential school is of good chemical quality but of poor bacteriological quality. It is recommended that the area in the vicinity of the spring be fenced off and no cattle or horses allowed inside. This fence should be built not less than 100 yards east of the spring and 200 yards to the south. If the bacteriological quality of the water does not improve then another source should be found, either a spring or a well. Since there is sometimes a shortage of water during certain periods of the year it might be well to investigate the possibilities of a well so that an adequate supply may be obtained the year round.

Stanley S. Deep
Sanitary Engineer, District No. 8.

Re Sacred Heart Indian Residential School

I have your letter of the 5th inst re the installing Insul Brick on the above school, and the question of delay, I took the matter up with the Contractor, and he was rather annoyed, as the quotation he gave in June, was not accepted till August, and then the Insul Brick did not arrive until three weeks later, he got started in September and although he had a certain amount of inclement weather, completed the St Cyprians Residential School, and also the Peigan Indian Hospital and I informed yo then that he hoped to get started on the Sacred Heart the week of October 16th to 22nd. This he did and during the last five weeks, he has done approximately one third of the School, however he has been badly handicapped with high winds, and severe cold weather and as the crew he puts on this job has only to be carried for the job on hand, it was a case of hiring a new crew every time he got a break in the weather, and during the last two weeks has been unable owing to the frosty weather to get at the work.

He advises that unless we get a warm calm spell he will not be able to do anything till the weather breaks, as the Insul brick in cold weather breaks, and also the hammer will punch ahole in the insul brick when stiff.

I will try and have this done whenever possible but with all contractors loaded with work it is a hard job to get them away from inside jobs.

I am writing you to advise that I have contacted a local man with a Bulldozer to come and plow out the road to the school, roads.

At the start of the storm which is now entering its fifth week, the snow plow was able to clear the roads, but with more than five days of blizzarding the road got so packed that the small plow was unable to move the large drifts.

The Sacred Heart School, which is always short of water, found themselves without water when school was supposed to start on January 9th, and as the truck was unable to get to Brocket to haul water from the C.P.R. tank, I took it upon myself to arrange for the opening of this road, and two miles to the St Cyprians School, so that the children may return to the Sacred Heart School. I hope to have all the children in school Sunday January 15th, and that the School by that time will have sufficient water in storage to carry on.

If we have some more blizzards it may be necessary to open the road again, and I trust you will concur in what I have done, and would like to have authority for the future if it is considered necessary.

This little girl, therefore, belongs to the class of orphan girls which you have kindly authorized me to accept: she is a real orphan indeed and worse off than many other orphans. She seems smart and perfectly healthy, and consequently I hope that you will kindly admit her.

Honorable Duncan C. Scott,

Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Lately while visiting the Sacred Heart Indian School on the Piegan Reserve, Brocket, Alberta, I have again discussed with Rev. Father Levern, Principal, the question of admitting some orphan half-breed girls to this school. This matter had previously been brought to your attention, as ascertained by your letter to Rev. Father Levern, dated Ottawa Sept. 30th 1927, giving full authorisation.

Consequently two girls, Loyer, were admitted in July 1928. Some time ago application for the admission of Laura Loyer, their younger sister, residing at Onion Lake, Sask., and also of another young girl, Louise Desjarlais, has been made; both girls are wards of the Dependent and Delinquent Children's Department at Edmonton. Apparently admission has been delayed by some misunderstanding somewhere. It appears that the Indian Department is demanding some informations concerning these two girls, their previous records of home, and concerning their parents. I have learned through one of its officials that the Department of Dependent and Delinquent Children is perfectly aware of all the conditions and circumstances of the children under its care, and if it agrees to have them transferred to the Indian School at Brocket, knows very well that these children will be incorporated into the Indian Band and that there is no objection whatever to this, and that no trouble from any source would be raised from any source, and thus is willing to the transfer without submitting to a scrutinous questionnaire about these young children.

Therefore may I ask that your Department should not insist upon obtaining such detailed particularities as apparently required by some of the late correspondence through the Indian Agent's Office. The admission of the two Loyer girls in July 1928 was effected without any of these formalities and objected to by the Dept. of Dependent and Delinquent Children, Edmonton, and who makes a clear and simple transfer of these young girls to the Indian Department; these girls are simply orphans and have no bad previous records.

The Piegan Indian Band has not ceased to insist that these young girls and other young half-breed gizim orphans should be, upon their admission to the school, be at once taken into the Band and not to wait till their discharge and marriage with a member of the Indian Band. The fact is that today the girls, previously admitted, have been already taken into the Band by an unanimous vote and are on Treaty Tickets.
For the sake of the race, several of the Piegan young men, ex-pupils, are wishing to have the opportunity of marrying these outside girls thus admitted to the school, as they are of better health and dispositions.

I hope and pray, Dear Sir, that you will deign to again take up this matter with Rev. Fr. Levern, Principal of the Sacred Heart School at Brocket, and communicate with him on this particular subject.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

I am directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, in connection with certain girls whom you desire admitted to the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School.

In giving the decision in 1927 to favourably consider the admission to the Sacred Heart Residential School of half-breed girls who will remain on the reserve after graduation, the Department provided that each case would have to be decided on its own merits and that the initial steps should be taken at the office of the Indian Agent. Consequently, it is necessary that full information regarding the antecedents of each girl for whom application is made should be supplied to the Indian Agent. The Department desires definite assurance that applicants are half-breeds, physically fit and have normal mentality.

I note that, at the present time, you suggest the admission to the Sacred Heart Residential School of Laura Loyer and Louisa Desjarlais. Please let Mr. Indian Agent Lancaster have complete information regarding these two girls. I am today advising him that he can expect to hear from you in the near future and that, as soon as he does so, he should report to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. A. Naessens, O.M.I.,
9916 - 110th St.,
Edmonton, Alta.

Sir,

I note that one of these girls is only five years old, which is under the age for admission of a pupil to an Indian residential school.

In giving the decision in 1927 to favourably consider the admission to the Sacred Heart Residential School of half-breed girls who will remain on the reserve after graduation, the Department provided that full information should be given regarding the antecedents of each girl for whom application is made. Please let me have, as soon as possible, complete information regarding the two Gladu girls and, on receipt of your report, further consideration will be given to the question of admitting them to the Sacred Heart School.

I desire, also, to direct your attention to official letters of December 19th, 1930, and May 7th, 1931. It is noted that you have not yet replied to either of these letters and the Department would appreciate hearing from you with regard to the matters mentioned in them.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit you the following particulars about pupil No. 0102 (Clara Noosekeye):

She is a Cree half-breed, born in Calgary. Her mother was already separated from her husband when she gave birth to that child and died a few days later; the poor little one was picked up by a good lady who brought her to our school, when she was only seven weeks old. This dear little orphan girl has been here since, and will be five years old this summer; she is very bright and perfectly healthy and has been admitted into the Peigan Indian Band two years ago.

Therefore I hope that you will kindly approve her admission into our school.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain, dear Sir,

Yours sincerely,

The Honourable H. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I hereto acknowledge receipt of your Circular of the 15th inst., No I-I-IO, and to say in reply that since the opening of this school in 1906 we have always kept the pupils until they reached the age of eighteen years. I beg to say also that, if we are obliged to discharge them when they are sixteen years of age, the only thing to do is to close this small school on this small reserve, where there are so few children and where it is so difficult to get them from their parents.

On the other hand, the long experience of many past years has shown that school girls should never be returned single to the reserve, where they would be exposed to too many dangers; the practice that has always been followed is to arrange their marriage during their last year of school and to celebrate their wedding on the day of their discharge. A few exceptions have taken place for different reasons, but in most cases it has been to the detriment of the girls.

As for the boys, I must say that since the Department has obliged us to run a farm in connexion with the school, I do not see at all how we could discharge them at sixteen; They start to work on the farm, as a rule, only when they have reached that age. Then, what would be the use of a farm? No training could be given them in that line, and besides, the grant should be increased in order to enable us to hire extra men to do the work.

Hoping that you will understand these reasons and allow us to continue to do as in the past, I remain, dear Sir,

Your humble Servant,

[Signature]
Principal.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the request of Paul White Cow for the discharge of his son from the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School.

The principal of the residential school concerned and yourself are the two persons who are most conversant with the facts when application is made for the discharge of a pupil. Consequently, the Department expects that, when an Indian Agent receives an application for the discharge of a pupil, he should consult the principal. The Agent is aware of local conditions while the principal knows the progress that the pupil has made in his school work. Therefore, an application received from a parent for the discharge of his child should not be forwarded to the Department simply as a matter of course, but the principal and the Indian Agent should confer on the request and, as a result of their deliberations, make a definite recommendation stating whether or not they consider it advisable to grant the request for discharge.

I feel you are under a misapprehension regarding the circular letter forwarded some months ago to principals of residential schools. This letter, a copy of which is enclosed, simply pointed out that the Indian Act provides that children are kept in a residential school after they reach the age of sixteen years, that the permission of the Department must be secured. Principals were requested to forward a list of the children in their schools who were sixteen years of age and over, and, in the case of those whom it was considered should be kept for a longer period, they were requested to state their reasons. When they forwarded this information, they were informed that at the end of each academic year in future they should forward through the office of their local Indian Agent a list of pupils sixteen years of age and over, as mentioned above, and state their reasons for desiring to keep any pupil after such pupil reaches the age of sixteen years.

I note your opinion that the school principals regard the Agent as having no authority over the schools or children, and I presume you refer particularly to the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School. In order that there may be no misunderstanding, I enclose, for your information, a copy of letter which is being directed to the Principal of that school.

In view of your statement that you consider the White Cow boy would be better off in school until Spring, the Department believes it undesirable to discharge him at the present time. He may, however, be discharged at the end of March, when he will be able to help his father with the Spring work.

Your obedient servant,

H. G. Lancaster, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Brocket, Alta.

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, January 2, 1935.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has been corresponding with Mr. Agent Lancaster regarding a request which he received for the discharge of the son of Paul White Cow from the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School. Mr. Lancaster believes this boy would be as well off in the school until Spring. He is being informed that the Department considers that the boy should be retained in the Sacred Heart School until the end of March, at which time he should be discharged, in order that he can help his parents.

Mr. Lancaster further points out that White Cow has two other children of school age, and if the son was discharged, he would be willing to send the two younger children, but wishes to place them in the Church of England School, as his wife is a Protestant, and he claims he no longer belongs to the Roman Catholic faith.

In replying to Mr. Lancaster, we are pointing out that, when a request for the discharge of a pupil is received, the Department expects the Indian Agent and the principal to consider the matter jointly. The Indian Agent is aware of the home conditions and the principal knows the progress the pupils is making in his school work. Consequently, when a request is received for discharge, the Indian Agent and the principal should consider the matter, and the Indian Agent should then write the Department making a definite recommendation either for or against the request for discharge.

As you were informed in official letter of June 26th last, it is not the Department's intention to insist on the discharge of children simply because they have reached the age of sixteen years, but, in order to carry out the provisions of the Act, principals are required, when pupils reach the age of sixteen years, to apply to the Department for permission to keep them for a further period. You will remember that in the last paragraph of official letter of June 26th you were further informed that, at the end of each academic year in future, you should forward to the Department, through the office of your local Indian Agent, a list of children in your school who are sixteen years of age and over. When presenting this list to the Indian Agent to send to the Department, you should go over each case with him and the two of you should decide whether or not it is better to keep certain children or discharge them.

The Department trusts that the Indian Agent and yourself will co-operate fully in connection with future discharges.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir,

Just a few lines to tell you that Sister Gertrude is still waiting for the book-case, which you promised her for the class-room; she will be very much obliged indeed if she gets it.

I wish to speak to you also about something else: it is this, I have been told that at the Calgary Convention you have publicly repeated that it is not the intention of the Department to discharge the pupils at sixteen. Now, the trouble is that the Pelican Indians still remember well what Mr. Christianson told them last year: "The law is changed... From now on, your children will leave the school at Sixteen..." More than that: they understood "as soon as they are coming on sixteen..." and therefore, since then, they are trying to get their children out, as soon as they are fifteen!

You may easily imagine all the trouble that this is causing me, and consequently it seems to me that Mr. Christianson should be told to go and let the Indians know that such is not the case. Otherwise, it will be a source of continual difficulties.

The Sisters and myself, we have kept a delicious souvenir of your visit to our small school and thank you for your great kindness towards us.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, September 4th, 1935.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, in which he states that the Peigan Indians are under the impression that children must be discharged from a residential school when they reach the age of sixteen years.

As you are aware, Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act provides that, for valid reasons, the Department is given authority to consent to children remaining in a residential school until they reach the age of eighteen years.

While some children should be discharged at sixteen, I think you will agree that it is in the best interests of others to remain until they are eighteen years of age. This applies particularly to the girls.

On the occasion of your next visit to the Peigan Agency, I should appreciate if you would discuss this matter fully with Mr. Agent Lancaster and the Indians and point out the exact meaning of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education,

M. Christianson, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

Brocket, Sept 30, 1936.

Dear Mr. Lancaster,

Concerning the enclosed applications for admission into our School, I regret to say that Charles Crow Eagle and Mrs. Two Chiefs have refused to sign. Charles has told me publicly that he will put all his children here, but will not sign the application for the admission of any of them—on account of what happened to his daughter "Gertrude." In fact, when he put his other son "Francis" here, he did the same.

Mrs. Two Chiefs says that she wants her grand son "Philip Yellow Wings" to be educated here, but she claims that she's too old to sign the application.

Hoping that this will create no objection to the admission of those two children, I remain yours truly,

J. L. Levern, O.M.

January 16th, 1930.

T.W. Victor Webb,
Indian Agent,
Brocket, Alta.

Dear Sir,

Following our conversation concerning John William English, Pupil IO4 of the Sacred Heart School, Brocket, I beg to make this statement:
That, having taken the matter of his standing in class with his teacher, and of his relations with the other boys, with the disciplinarian, I have found that this boy John William English, although not an extra bright pupil is far from being what his father would like us to believe, namely that his boy cannot and will never learn anything, and that he is abused by the other children. It is true that the boy stutters and has difficulty to express himself; he is what a school Inspector would term a pupil below the average. His teacher states that the intelligence is fair but the memory defective.

Otherwise, he is physically strong and healthy and can and in fact does very well look after himself. Personally, I believe it would be too bad to deprive the boy of the chance he has to learn: with many children the intelligence develops slowly, as may be the case with him.

Sincerely yours,

(Signed) E. Riaux, O.M.I.

(COPY)
Sir,

I have a request from John English one of our Peigan Indians who has a boy in school at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, aged 13 years, named Willis on the Treaty Book, and registered on the school books as John William English.

I understand he is practically a mute & of sub-normal intellect, and the father asks that he be discharged from school to return home. The father claims he would be better at home and could assist him around the place, and states that the boy is very good working around farming at home, and would be of great assistance when the father is laid up with periodic attacks of arthritis.

Father E. Riaux as per my request has submitted his observations on the boy, and I am appending a copy of his letter to me, and beg to ask a decision from the Department.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

T. W. Victor Webb,
Indian Agent.

With reference to your letter No.116-2-10 of the 15th inst.; enclosing letter of J.L.Bissett, asking for the adoption of a child in the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School at this Reserve.

This little girl "Clara No-se-keys" was taken care of as a baby by the sisters at this school, later June 23rd, 1930, she was taken in to Treaty with The Peigan Band, after a vote was taken which was approved by Department letter No.62-116 June 23rd, 1930. Since then one of our Headmen Leo Smith, adopted her by consent of the Principal, he treats her well & she likes the Smiths.

Under the circumstances outlined above I would suggest that the girl remain at this school until time for discharge, then she should decide her own future. She is now 11 years old.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Clara No-se-keys, No. B.65

I am writing you in regard to the above girl, who was recently discharged from Sacred Heart school, having reached the age limit.

The girl is not a Peigan Indian but was admitted to the Band along with seven others under authority of Departmental Letter No. 62-116 dated June 23rd 1930 and has no relations on the reserve.

She has an aunt however, a Mrs Bessette, the wife of J.L. Bessette of J.L. Bessette & Son, General Merchants, Notikewin, Alta. I have recently had a letter from Mr Bessette expressing his willingness to take Clara & provide for her & was wondering what the reaction of the Department would be to his.

I might say that Clara is temporarily employed at the school until such time as a proper home can be found for her.

I understand that Mrs Bessette has been down here on previous occasions trying to get the child from the school, but apparently was headed off, but whether the matter was ever taken up with you, I do not know.

S.T. Faunt,
Acting Indian Agent.

Re: Clara Nosekay, No. B.65.

I have your letter of 15th Inst., in regard to the above girl, written in reply to mine of 10th Inst.

It would appear that you were under the impression that I had not discussed this girl's case with the principal of the school, but this is not the case.

When the matter of discharge came up, the question of the girl's future was talked of & the Rev'd Father spoke of the aunt & agreed to make enquiries as to their position, character &c. before letting the girl go to them, as she wanted to do.

I then wrote to the people asking them if they were still anxious to have her & they said they were & would arrange to come after her at any time they were advised that they could have her.

The Principal, on talking to him this morning, says there is no future for her on the reserve & it would be in the girl's best interests that she should go to her own people.

So far as working at the school is concerned, I asked the Principal if he could not arrange to give her something to do till such time as satisfactory arrangements could be made for her and I might say that at present she is an observation case as the result of an X-Ray examination in connection with a T.B. clinic recently held, and is not working.

J.T. Faint,
Acting Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
March 4, 1944.

Mr. J.T. Faunt, Acting Indian Agent, Brocket, Alta.

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, in further reference to Clara Nosekeye.

If you refer to official letter of the 15th ultimo you will note that before writing to you at that time we had reviewed the correspondence between the Department and the Peigan Indian Agency office at the time this girl was admitted to membership in the band. No doubt you have also read the correspondence to which we refer and you are aware of the particular circumstances that induced the Department to encourage her admission to the Peigan Band.

Before placing the girl in charge of Mr. and Mrs. Bessette, we feel that legal adoption papers should be taken out by them. As stated above, this girl is a member of an Indian band and, if we simply allow her to go to the home mentioned and things do not work out satisfactorily, she will be left without anyone to look after her. We do not wish this condition to arise and I think both the Principal and yourself will recognize the importance of arranging legal adoption.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I beg to make the following report on the Case of Mrs. Annie Yellow Wings whose case of Arson was concluded by the Police and the question of her Sanity placed before the Doctor for this Agency.

I am enclosing a copy of the report of Dr. Brayton who examined this woman two weeks ago, and has just presented his written report. I believe the remarks of Dr. Brayton are very close to the correct reason for the actions of this woman.

After the Doctors examination, I had Mrs. Yellow Wings in the Office with the Police Scout and after talking the whole matter over I warned her that although prosecution was concluded, for the time being that if she got herself into any further trouble that the old case might be brought up again, and reminded her that for the next four years her behaviour would have to be of the best.

The problem which now places itself before me is the request of the mother for her children; she has a baby and the second youngest child with her, while Guy Yellow Wings her husband, has the other two children aged 5 and 6. Guy however is not taken these children under his control, he has placed them in the home of his Sister, Mrs. Paul Smith, who have their own children to look after as well. Guy is travelling around the country making his home at MacLeod where he has some work, and is co-habiting with a girl of similar character to the one he left behind. Guy Yellow Wings is living by herself in her own home, and has requested that she have the two older children with the intention of placing them in the Anglican School immediately; Although I have not seen Guy Yellow Wings I understand he wishes to put them in the Catholic School. I would like your advice regarding the action to be taken and whether you would consider accepting Mrs. Guy Y Wings application for admission, or The Husband's, I would on the knowledge I have be inclined to favor the mothers signature as she seems to be mostly interested in the children.

It is my intention to try and straighten out this case by having them both come to the Office, but would not like to make any statement re the children till I have had your advice.

For three months previous to the Arson case this family were only together for short periods the husband meeting the other woman in Macleod during that time; and although Mrs. Guy Yellow Wings has committed a crime the loss of her child during the Xmas season plus the trouble she had with her husband calls for a grain of sympathy.

I will be glad of your instructions and advice regarding the School I should place these children in, and any further suggestions I should take in settling up their troubles. It is certain that it will be an impossibility to get them together again.

Anthony McMillan,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 16, 1945.

Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent, Brocket, Alberta.

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the two children of Mrs. Annie Yellow Wings. Under these circumstances, it is felt that the father should be allowed to direct the religion under which the children should be educated, and therefore you might submit application forms and certificates of health for their admission to the Sacred Heart School.

Philip Phelan,

Attention Philip Phelan Esqr.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter File 116-2-10 of the 31st March.

Regarding the cases of Rosaline Yellow Wings, and Joseph Yellow Wings, these are the children of Guy Yellow Wings and his wife, who after trouble in the family separated when Mrs Yellow Wings burnt down their home, and the elder children were taken in charge by Guy Yellow Wings, at that time I reported the matter and as the father was not considered living correctly it was agreed to have the Children put in School; your letter of February 16th File 116-2-10 advised me to put the children in the Sacred Heart School, and I trust that this will still be allowed, as this may cause further argument if he is discharged.

The case of Catherine Stump who when I arrived here was a permanent patient in the Peigan Hospital, owing to the filthy house she had to live in with her mother, and the state of her health; When the Doctor gave Catherine a clear sheet, I took the matter up with Father Crepeau, and he stated his willingness to take this child into School; this girl has a cleft palate, and would be in a precarious position if she was sent forward to her mother's home; I would recommend that these applications be allowed even if the children are under age.

I beg to request That I be given the following advice;

A girl by the name of Doris Rabbit was admitted to the Sacred Heart School by authority of your letter File 116-2-10 of November 10th 1941. From the information I am able to get from the Sacred Heart Principal and files this girl was placed in school as the mother was not capable of looking after her, this child up to 16 months ago I understand was being taken care of by the school, when at that time this girl was turned over to Harold Sharp Adze, which the Sacred Heart Principal states was arranged between him and the Agent at that time.

Harold Sharp Adze has now signed papers for the admission of this child to the Anglican School, claiming guardianship owing to having looked after this child for the last eighteen months, he took the Child to the Anglican School last Friday.

This is being stoutly argued by the Principal of the Sacred Heart School, who was very indignant, and annoyed when bringing this to my attention.

I have advised the Principal of the St Cyprians School by letter to return this child to Harold Sharp Adze while the Department make a decision; this will be done immediately and the child left with the Guardians till a decision is arrived at. This Girl Doris Rabbit will not be seven till February 25th 1946.

I am enclosing a copy of the Application for admission which I received from the Principal of the Anglican School which I trust you will return after you have looked it over with further instructions.

Anthony J. Millar
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 15th September, 1945.

Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent, Brocket, Alberta.

I have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to Doris Rabbit. This girl was regularly admitted to the Sacred Heart School in the Fall, 1941, and the application form states that her father was dead at that time and the form was signed by the mother and approved by the Agent Mr. T.W.V. Webb. Her religion was stated to be Roman Catholic. The Quarterly Returns from the school show that she was allowed out for holidays on June 30th, 1944, and did not return on the expiry of her leave.

In view of the above, the Department considers that this girl should be returned immediately to the Sacred Heart Residential School. We are not prepared to approve her admission to the St. Cyprians School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

STATEMENT MADE BY MRS ANNIE RABBIT BEFORE INDIAN AGENT,
AT OFFICE.

Doris Rabbit was turned over to Harold Sharp Adze owing to mother being a widow and could not take care of her, after having taken the child over Harold Sharp Adze was convicted and sent to Jail and the child was turned back to the mother, and she asked the R.C Principal to take the child into School. This child then was just over a year old, and authority was granted to place the child in the School.

This child stayed in School till June 1944 and was turned back to Sharp Adze, who looked after the child each summer. Last fall he went to the U.S.A. to work and the child was not returned to School being under school age.

During this period she never asked the return of the child, and harold has been keeping it since it left school.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. P. Melan
Chief, Education Division

This has reference to your memorandum of April 7th re Bernadette Yellow Face, Peigan Reserve.

This is a matter for administrative decision at discretion as provided by sub-section (1) of Section 10 of the Indian Act to which you refer.

The wording of the Section, "...that where it has been made to appear to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General (Minister) that it would be detrimental to any particular Indian child to have it discharged from school on attaining the full age of sixteen years, the Superintendent General (Minister) may direct that such child be detained at school for such further period as may seem to be advisable, but not beyond the full age of eighteen years,...", appears to be apposite to this case.

The facts as stated in the correspondence to which you refer and also in the statement of the child, Bernadette Yellow Face, herself in my opinion give ample justification for keeping the girl in school until she is 18 years of age.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary,

I am having trouble with the R.C. School on account of my oldest girl. She is kept back at the school when over a holiday come on, the rest of the school boys and girls all go home at Easter time. She stayed back for 10 days; she is not allowed to come home with us. Whenever we go there, they don't show up. They say no notice was given. They are telling her she was not fit to marry. I have written to the principal. He got his brother at the school, he will look after my daughter to marry him. This fellow has been friendly with the girl. My daughter said she didn't want him at all. I told her to tell him to keep his sisters by his side too. You can't go by the Indian agent's orders. This man has been seen with my daughter going around with her alone. My daughter says he is too old for me.
He is too gray hair man and I am too young yet him for my husband.

My daughter told the other school girls that principal and the agent a parish priest will look for a job for her and I don't think I will be able to come back. They told me never to go home again more, to keep off from home because my flock are too poor that no place for you to be.

Well this is my greatest reason why I change my children to the other school, so my children would be better like this again.

It looks to me that my days there going to be chase out from the teacher I'm not a kid free to see her.

On May the 6th all children went home up to Sunday my daughter was wanting
to come home with the next, the next day will be her birthday she will be 16 she want to go home she was just jumping for joy girls to girl she told I before I shake it home this time to see my dear mother & dad? Then it will be Mother's day too She told them if she could come home they told her The government wrote you should not be home On Feb 20th I went to the school I ask for my oldest daughter to leave school I wanted her to get married when she will be 16 she likes the boy all right they all had a hold event too At the time the girl was
At the time the girl she went to dances and to town with him. That's Archie Big Swan they want to visit his home. The girl she so like the place she wanted to stay there I went for her to get back. It was time for them to go back to school she told me. I hate to go back. Now look how they are doing in the first place. Dear the agent, Patrick Price the Scout to let my daughter come of that School today they all calling down the boy I got for Son-in-Law. I have a trust in thee.

From

Mr Sam Yellow Face

Re: Sacred Heart Res. School
Application Valerie Yellow Wings:

Reference is made to your letter of January 8, 1953 regarding the application of Valerie Yellow Wings, to the Sacred Heart Residential School. It is regretted that this application was forwarded without a covering letter of explanation.

Valerie Yellow Wings is a child of a very poor family. The mother often abandons the child and the father is a very poor provider. As the child reached the age of six years on December 4th, 1952, I considered it would be in order to submit her application, when the principle stated he would make room for her in his school.

Although as stated in your letter, the Sacred Heart Residential School has more than authorized enrollment, could consideration be given to the approval of this application, due to the circumstances of the child's home.

Sir:-

I am in receipt of a letter from the Rev. Father Levern, Principal of the R.C. Indian Residential School on the Peigan Reserve, who asks to be supplied with certain equipment this Spring, in order that he may start to prepare a farm before the new school is in operation, which I think is a very wise plan. He asks for three sets of harness, plow with breaker bottom, disk, waggon and anything else that may be required. He asks for six work horses. I do not know that I am prepared to recommend the purchase of six horses, as I think four should be ample, but the implements asked for seem to me to be necessary.

I shall be glad to know if this equipment can be supplied to the school.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 11, 1926.

Sir:

I have your 406-11A of the 6th instant, with reference to supplying agricultural machinery and work horses for the Peigan R. C. Indian Residential School. I should like to know what equipment and stock this school has at the present time. Our funds are extremely limited and only the most pressing requisitions can be given favourable consideration. The Department would like to deal favourably in this connection, but it will be necessary to know what are the minimum requirements for successful farming operations this year on the new site.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Sir:

I am in receipt of Department letter No. 116-2-5 of the 11th instant, in connection with the supplying of agricultural machinery and work horses for the Peigan Roman Catholic Indian Residential School. I wish to inform you that this school has nothing in the way of implements, as they have previously done no farming as the school was situated on a gravel bed where it was not possible to do any farming. The only things that I would recommend for the use of the school this year would be; 2 teams of horses, 2 sets of harness, a plow, a disc and a set of harrows.

I shall be glad to have your authority to make this purchase.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham

My dear Mr. Scott:

Reverend Father J. L. Levern, Principal of Peigan Indian Residential School, had requested from the Department the purchase of a few horses and agricultural implements, all of which were to be used in order to prepare the land for next year.

If my memory serves me right, the Department advised Mr. Graham on June 13th to comply with the Reverend Principal's request. On July 25th, the Commissioner answered the Department that the above articles were not needed for the present year. Of course, he knows best.

On September 25th, Reverend Father Levern spoke of the necessity he had for horses and the implements to Mr. Christianson but on October 16th no news had been received as yet. The Reverend Principal insists upon the urgent need of horses, at least to bring over different things from the old school to the new one. Do you think that he could be accommodated and therefore given authority to buy a few horses for his present needs?

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,

REGINA, SASK., Dec. 8th, 1926.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report on the progress of the two new schools that are being erected on the Peigan Reserve.

The Roman Catholic School is pretty well advanced. The outside of the building was nearly finished and the lathers were at work when I was there and the plasterers arrived the day I left. The plumbing and steamfitting was also well under way, as they expected to be able to turn on the heat as soon as the chimney was finished which they were working at then. The outbuildings which I arranged for on my last visit were also well under way and should be nearly completed now. The Contractor expects to finish the school about the 15th of January.

The Church of England School is not as far advanced. They have, however, made good headway since my last visit. The walls were up as far as the roof, but the part housing the engines and so forth at the back of the school had not been started on, simply the foundation put in.

The barn and other outbuildings which I arranged for on my last visit were almost completed. The men expected to finish a day or so after I left. They have made a very fine job of the buildings and the Principal was highly satisfied with the buildings and the workmanship.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
the workmanship in general. Mr. Graham, the Contractor on the school, thought he would be able to finish up by the end of January. I doubt this; if he puts on enough men, he will no doubt be able to finish it by then, but the weather will be a big factor in the matter.

Regarding the implements and horses asked for by the Principal of the Roman Catholic School and authorized by the Department. The implements, of course, are not needed at the present time but the two teams of horses asked for, which I had your authority to purchase, will soon be required. However, I found that the Principal was not in a position to take the horses at the present time as I knew previously. He has only a small amount of feed and no place to keep them at the present time. I, however, picked out some horses and instructed Mr. Arthur to purchase them at such times when the Principal would be ready to take delivery of them. I did not think it wise to buy the horses now and take delivery of them and turn them out on the prairie.

I did not visit the Church of England School, but I was over at the Roman Catholic School and I had the Principal from the Anglican School up to the office to see me. On the whole, conditions are satisfactory at both schools.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th instant #116-2-14, in which you authorize me to purchase a wagon for use at the Sacred Heart (Peigan R.C.) Indian Residential School, and reply to say that this matter will be attended to, although I think that a wagon is unnecessary. The question of supplying a wagon was discussed with the Inspector who recently visited the Peigan Agency, and he told me that he thought they could very well get along without one. However, they took this matter up direct with you and I am now authorized to buy the wagon. I think you will admit this puts the Inspector in a very awkward position. It would be much better for the Inspectors not to say anything about matters of this kind, as they would not then be placed in the positions which they sometimes are. Personally I think it would be much safer to rely on the word of the Inspector than on that of the Principal or the Indian Agent. There is a tendency, as you know, on the part of the school authorities to get as much as they possibly can out of the Department when a new school is opened up. We know that they have a good wagon at this school at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

H.C. Lancaster,
Indian Agent, Brocket.

Dear Sir,

I regret very much to tell you that we are out of water: This morning we were not able to get any water from the old well neither from the spring, although we pumped for a long time.

As you are well aware, a short while after we moved into this school, we built a good dam across the coulee at a certain distance from the spring in order to gather all the water running from it and to form a pond for our stock. This pond has given perfect satisfaction until the spring was piped to the house; since that time, there has been no overflow running into it; however, the melting of the snow and some occasional heavy rains have kept it almost full the most of the time till this summer. It is dry now: it went dry last week, and therefore we started to pump for the stock as well as for the house, and that is how we ran out of water.

After all, this has not surprised me: the same trouble happened already last Christmas, just because we used on that occasion more water than usual. There is very little water in the old well, and the spring itself has never been strong, as Mr. Gardner-Smith stated it in his letter of October 1931 to the Department.

Still, I hope that by using it sparingly, we may get water enough for the house and the milch cows; but we must absolutely send the rest of the stock somewhere else, where they can drink. Napoleon Provost is willing to take charge of them at his place near the river, for $25.00 a month; I hope that the Department will approve of this arrangement and pay this monthly bill.

If we have a good rain to fill the pond again before the winter, we will be glad to take them back to the school; if not, we will have to leave them there and to take the trouble of hauling hay for them to that distance of six miles!

Under all these hard circumstances, it would be much more pleasant indeed for me to have no cattle at all here; but then how could I run this small school and pay all the expenses if I had to depend on no other revenue than the per Capita Grant?

Hoping that you will kindly communicate about this matter with the Department as soon as possible, I remain, dear Sir,

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal
August 26th, 1933.

Sir,

I enclose herewith a letter received from Mr. Tavern, Principal of the R.C. school on this reserve in reference to the water situation at the school. In regard to this I may say that owing to the drought this year spring on the reserve are running very little water and our range conditions both for water and grass are very poor.

The R.C. school here were given an extra quarter of land to enable them to raise feed for their stock; they are farming on a large scale and have about eighty head of cattle and it is water in this quantity of stock that has caused most of their water shortage and I think something should be done to have them cut down their herd. They claim the prices are low and they do not wish to sacrifice stock but the Indians have to do it and these cattle being turned on our range makes that much less feed and water for the Indian stock and I do not think the department is in any way responsible for the $25.00 per month they wish to pay the Indian for looking after the stock.

It appears to me that the welfare of the Indian children is a secondary consideration with our boarding schools now and that most of their exercises are directed toward making money in farming and raising stock and that they should only be allowed to raise or hold the number of stock that can be pastured and fed on the land allotted to them.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

H.O. Lancaster,
Indian Agent.

Re: Complaints of principal, Brocket School, Alta.
ATTENTION: Mr. F. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father G. Crépeau, O.M.I., of the above school, in which he complains of the damages that one of the bulls of the Agency has caused to the milk herd of the school. It appears that this bull fought a royal battle with the school bull and broke the fence around the latter's corral. To keep the peace the school bull had to be killed eight months before he was to have been disposed of.

It also appears that this same Agency bull attacked a cow and so violently that it tore an eye out of its socket and the cow had to be killed immediately.

These complaints were made to the Agent and the stockman without any avail. The bull is still on the school premises and is continuing to cause very serious damage. Father Crépeau says that his claim for the above is $250.00 and asks the Department to pay it without any delay.

The above complaints seem a little strange, I admit, but if true, something should be done about it, as agents must protect not only the property of the Indians, but to the same degree that of the Department of Indian Affairs. Attention B F Neary Esqr.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th inst File 116-2-14 (W T 1).

As you state this is an usual letter; and would seem to be a very petty complaint of the past Principal. I approached the new Principal for information this being the first I had heard of it, also my Stockman, and the Clerk in the Office to find if any such complaint had been made. It was found that the phone calls advising me that the Bull was in their field was all the Principal said. The new Principal advises me as follows that according to his employees, the Bull occasionally got into the field and when possible, battled the School Bull, but without damage. The question of the Cow is very far fetched, no one saw the cow attacked, the cow is still alive without the sight of one eye, and according to School employees they do not know how the cow got hurt.

Our Bulls are only out for July, August, and part of September, and the rest of the year are in the Bull pasture 12 miles from the School; Every time we received a complaint one of our stockmen went down and removed the Bull and put it on the Range. However the main dam on our summer range where approximately 1200 cattle and 25 Bulls congregate is only one mile from the School fence, and we cannot control them all the time.

In conversation with the new Principal, he advises me that he intends to have a change of breeding cattle at the School and will likely change from Jersey's to shorthorns, if so he intends to ask permission to use our Bulls at odd times, so that I see no reason for this matter coming up again.

The claim is ridiculous, as the animal supposed to have been killed immediately is still very much alive, while I am advised the Bull was undamaged.

Anthony McMillan
Indian Agent.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representatives shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Sir,

I regret to have to inform the population of the death (accidental) of Josephine Little Leaf, Treaty No. 671, of this reserve.

The child was 7 years and two months of age, had just been placed in the Sacred Heart School the 1st of September but application forms had not yet been sent in to this office.

It appears several of the girls had been playing with a four wheel trailer that is used by the school to haul supplies when on a slight incline the trailer got out of control and ran backward down the incline and crushed Josephine between the trailer and the ice house, crushing her chest and causing internal hemorrhage, and she died in a few minutes.

An inquest was held yesterday and the coroner jury exonerated the staff at the school in the matter. One of the Sisters was with the girls at the time.

My name is Sister St. Clotilde. I am second disciplinarian for the girls at Sacred Heart School Brochet Alta, and was on duty at 7 P.M. Sept 12, 1937. Here is what happened while on duty. I took the small girls to the chicken coop for a visit. On our way back to the girls' playground, they saw the trailer which is used to bring supplies to the school from Brochet and they began to play with it. Some girls pulling at the front and others pushing at the back, and some others taking a ride by turn and going forward and turning around and coming back a short distance, and then all of a sudden the trailer came at a place where the ground is sloping a little towards the ice house. I was standing about 20 feet from the trailer. Three girls were riding inside the boy, two were pulling at the front and two were pushing at the back: Josephine Little Leaf and Laura Black Eyes. Some girls standing by a little way, seeing the trailer backing on the ice house, shouted to stop. Laura Black Eyes jumped aside. Josephine Little Leaf remained behind and was crushed between the back of the trailer and the wall of the ice house. The trailer rebound, and Josephine ran to me and I ran towards her—took her in my arms, her legs gave way under her, thinking she was fainting. I left her on the ground, ran for water to wash her face, on my return I noticed a little blood coming though the nose and the mouth. I shook her a little to revive her without success.
then I ran to the house to get the matron who came at once with all the sisters of the staff—Sister Armstrong first. Disciplining of the girls felt the pulse and could not feel any movement; we carried Josephine little girl to the girl infirmary and laid her on a bed. Sister Armstrong went to telephone to the doctor. It was about 5 P.M. When Josephine was caught between the trailer and the wall of the ice house, and 5.15 when she was on the bed at the infirmary. The doctor arrived from Pincher Creek about at 6.30. When I saw the girls playing with the trailer I never thought that such an accident might happen.

Sister St. Clotilde.

Re: Josephine LITTLE LEAF... Peigan Indian Reserve, Brocket Alta., Accidental death of - Internal Hemorrhage

1. At about 7.05 P.M. 12th Sept. 1937, Dr. K.J. Brayton phoned me from Sacred Heart Roman Catholic School on Peigan Indian Reserve that a little Indian Girl had been killed at that place the evening before he had been called in but the child was dead when he arrived.

2. I proceeded to Peigan Reserve at once making the patrol by pte auto.

3. Upon arrival at the school I found the body of a little Indian girl (Josephine Little Leaf) lying on a bed in the girl's infirmary. There was a slight depression on the left side of breast; bloody matter was oozing from the nostrils and mouth. No bruises or scars.

4. I took statements from persons at the School knowing anything about the matter using both French and Indian interpreters to do so.

5. There are no suspicious circumstances surrounding this death. My investigation showed that the deceased was a little girl of 8 years of age an orphan had been living with her uncle on the reserve, his name being Chief John Yellow Horn. The little girls had come to the school the night of Sept. 1937. During the afternoon of the 12th Sept. 1937 six or seven little Indian Girls had gone out with Sister Ste Clotilde to look at the chickens in the Chicken house on their way back the children started to play with a trailer used by the school to pull supplies behind a car from Brocket. Two of the girls were pulling the trailer two were pushing it and three riding in it. They were taking turns at riding and pushing and pulling. Little Josephine had had her turn at riding and was taking her turn at pushing. They were attempting to turn the trailer at the top of a little incline leaning down to the garage and ice house, the trailer got the better of them and rolled down the incline crushing Josephine between the rear of the trailer and the wall of the ice house her chest was literally caved in she died in a few minutes bleeding inwardly so fast that the outer parts of the body did not discolor.

6. After getting the statements I phoned Sub-Div. headquarters at Lethbridge and was instructed to notify the coroner at MacLeod. I did this after I had notified the Indian Agent at Brocket Alta. The Coroner A.F. GRADY after hearing the result of my investigation ordered an Inquest to be held at the School next day at 9.30 A.M. and instructed me to have a jury ready.

Dear Sir,

Allow me to inform you, and through you the Honorable Minister of the Interior, that His Lordship Bishop Grandin desires the Industrial School of St Albert to be henceforth placed on a different footing.

Enclosed herewith, is a statement showing the general expenses incurred by the Institution for the support and maintenance of the St Albert Industrial School during the past year.

This sum, although apparently large, does not include the expense of providing the school with implements necessary for working in the garden, on the farm, tools for blacking boots, spinning wheels, wool carders, etc.

We would not encounter this great expenditure, were it not a fact that the produce of our farms, money gained by the industry of the Indians, etc., etc., etc.
charitable donations, etc., all go to buy clothes and educate these children, to keep their orphanage in repair, and provide furniture, light, and heat for each apartment.

The teachers' salaries, as teachers in the Public Catholic Schools, have again been maintained by the Diocesan School Board. Today, these salaries are greatly diminished, by the arrangements of our Local Government; consequently, it is utterly impossible for us to continue the work, unless we receive from the Government a sufficient grant that will enable us to meet all expenses.

We therefore request that a grant of $100 (one hundred dollars) be given, per annum, for each child in attendance at the St. Albert Orphanage School. I very much regret having to report to the Department that a boy pupil of the St. Albert School has made the attempt to burn the school down. The circumstances of the case are as follows:

For some time the boy has been trying to get out of the school and his father has been worrying to have him discharged - anything I refused to do as the lad is only 12 years of age. It seems that the boy has been talking to his brother-in-law one Trottier who it is said burned the St. Paul de Metis school down - in fact he brags about it today - and this Trottier told the boy that if he wanted to get out of the school all he had to do was to burn it down as he Trottier did the St. Paul School. The boy - so the Sisters tell me - got some matches and was going to pour coal oil on the floor of one of the rooms and then light it. The plot was discovered fortunately before he had time to put it into effect.

So far I have taken no action save to have the boy carefully watched and kept from the other pupils and also I have spoken to the Archbishop Legal on the matter who suggests that the boy be sent to the Qu'Appelle school. In this I agree for the reason that it would be very difficult to prove in a court that the boy really did contemplate burning the school down and it would never do to let him go unreproved. To send him to the Dunbow school would be no use as he would run away from there and so defy us again.

I therefore ask that authority be given for his transfer to the Qu'Appelle school at once.

Dear Sir,

I am shown a letter dated 8 February int. and signed by Mr. Scott concerning the boy Sam Callihoo, who had made some attempt on the 20th of Jan. last, to start a fire in the Indian Boarding School house at St. Albert and directing the Re. Mother of the institution to put the discovery of the boy out to remit him to his parents.

I wonder how such conclusion has been reached. It must not be forgotten that this was precisely the object sought out by this boy and his accomplice; namely to have the place burnt down so that they could all be turned out and returned to their families, as it had happened after the burning down of the St. Paul de Lévis Boarding School. Therefore, in place of a sanction it would be really a gratification granted to the boy, and an incentive to the other pupils to do the like.

I understand some lawyers at Edmonton have been interfering in this case. This is unfortunate. What do they know of the Indian temper and what instinct lies in their educational training?

It seems to me that the only sensible course to be taken would be, if not to take the boy immediately to the reformatory, at least to keep him, but to keep him in the school, under suspended sentence, and the intelligence that, on the first new offence, the sentence would be executed.

Hoping that this course will be sustained by the authority of this Department, I have the honour to remain, Dear Sir,

Your very respectfully,

Emile J. Pape,

Dear Sir,

ST. ALBERT SCHOOL, near Edmonton.

Here we find 43 boys and 37 girls very healthy and well cared for in a new and thoroughly modern building and under a most competent administration. There are 290 pupils altogether in this school, of whom 80 to 85 are Indians. In looking over the Indian children carefully I did not discover any who should be sent home. In general health and appearance they are all fully up to the standard of good health. Though a number have enlarged glands of the neck there are none suppurating or ulcerating and I am satisfied the very efficient care they receive in this institution should meet all requirements, and I can cheerfully commend this school as being well equipped and well managed in every particular.

In conclusion I would again mention only to emphasize the desirability that all Indian schools be provided with wide balconies properly screened so that the children may be kept in the open air to sleep during as much of the year as is practicable, and all the better if it be throughout the whole year, after sanitarium methods, as in this way alone can the prevalence of tuberculosis disease among the Indians be reduced and the health of the bands be brought up to a desirable standard.

Respectfully submitted,

F. A. Corbett, M.D.

I was exceedingly pleased with what I saw at St. Albert School. This is truly a wonderful place. The school building, just completed, is without doubt the finest Indian Institution I was ever in, large, airy and well lighted. The beds and bedding could not be better. There was no crowding, and the food was good and wholesome. The children looked the picture of health, as the Doctor's report bears out.

Mostly everything in the way of food used in this Institution is produced on the premises. The wheat is ground into flour at the mill nearby; the beef, pork, eggs, milk and fruit used in the School are raised or grown on the home farm.

W. M. Graham,
Commissioner.
