Honourable Sir James Lougheed,

I beg to send herewith important reports from the Indian Commissioner and Doctor F. A. Corbett, of Regina.

When I was in Regina last summer I had an interview with Doctor Corbett, and it was arranged that he should make these inspections. Doctor Corbett is greatly interested in the welfare of the Indians, and his report justifies the inspection.

I regret extremely that it is possible to draw such a comparison between the Protestant and Roman Catholic schools. The Creesfoot, Quinaskin's and St. Albert schools are all conducted by the Roman Catholic Church, while the Old Sun's and Sarcee are conducted by the Church of England. The comparison does not hold good over the whole field, however, as we have excellent Protestant schools in other parts of the country. The Anglican schools in the diocese of Calgary have always unfortunately been badly managed.

The conditions at the Old Sun's school are disgraceful, and the principal and medical attendant are worthy of serious censure for allowing such health conditions to exist.

As you are personally aware of the general conditions at the James reserve, this additional information with reference to the school and the Indians there will be of special interest. If the best is to be saved at all we must take vigorous measures and I would propose to turn the school into a hospital and to treat the whole reserve as a hospital area. These Indians have a large reserve and more of it should be turned into cash as soon as possible and used for their benefit, and the funds we have on hand should be fully used.

It would be advantageous if Doctor Corbett could continue his inspections and visit all our reserves and schools, but as he has a large practice in Regina, I do not think we could expect him to spend the necessary time in making inspectorial visits.

I should like to discuss these matters with you.

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Giroux:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, enclosing a copy of a communication you have received from the Sister Superior of St. Albert Indian Residential School. The nature of this school and its splendid results are well known to the officials of the Department of Indian Affairs; but, because it is largely engaged in the education of children who are not wards of the Federal Government and whereas the property is entirely church owned, it is considered that capital expense, except under quite exceptional circumstances, should be met by the school authorities.

The Department recently was unable to give favorable response to a request for replacements to the buildings and for new equipment. As you are aware, expenditures of this nature are precluded unless Parliament has provided the necessary funds. Our willingness to assist this school, when possible, with grants for other than current expenses, is proven by the fact that during the past two years over $4,000 has been expended for buildings and furnishings. One of the recent requests was for expensive playground equipment which the Department does not supply to Indian residential schools. However, a substitution was made, and there was provided athletic equipment which is considered suitable for Indian children.

Relative to the amount of the per capita grant, I wish to point out that the St. Albert institution ranks as a boarding school, and receives $165. Other schools in this category in Alberta receive as little as $140. The Edmonton Institution is an industrial one, and receives $170 per child, which is the amount of the grant for this class of school.

I regret that there are no funds available at the present time to assist with the necessary improvements. If requests are placed before the Department, the consideration due them will be given when future estimates are being prepared.

Dear Sir:

We were advised by a certain party, to write you personally and explain to you, in regard to our finances, how we are standing........

As you know, we had erected in 1920, a large building; and our only intention in having this building erected, was for the sole comfort of the Indians.... If we cannot recruit a number large enough to fill up the vacant places, this is not due to our negligence; as we have done and are always doing from day to day, what we can to take in the Indians and civilize them, to the best of our knowledge........

As this building has left a heavy debt on our shoulders, and the interests on this heavy amount eating up every cent we can spare leaves us at the present in a very critical condition..... This present year 1926, now on the spot, keeps us worrying from day to day, how we are to meet the heavy interests so near at hand.... Reverend and dear Sister Gosselin,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, asking for some financial assistance towards the capital expenditure at your school.

I beg to assure you that there is no institution in which we take a greater interest, but it would hardly be possible for us to come to your assistance as you desire. Dear Mr. Stewart,

During your visit to St. Albert this fall, you expressed your willingness to give the Rev. Grey Sisters some financial assistance in their severe losses.

We realize that your policy of building and maintaining your own schools makes it difficult for you to do justice to the Sisters of St. Albert, either by bonuses or otherwise.

Here the Rev. Grey Nuns, the pioneers in Indian and charitable work in the west, have built and maintained at their own expense an institution which represents several hundred thousand dollars.

There they are doing Indian work for the Government and because they have invested their own money and thereby saved the expense of building to the Department, they are penalized for it and cannot receive any compensation for their investment, risks and losses. Does that seem fair?

We know that no one is responsible for this. It is the result of circumstances. But we respectfully ask you, is that a justification for allowing present conditions to remain. Would it not be better and fairer to all parties concerned to have the Government offer to buy the St. Albert school from the Rev. Sisters and run it as it runs its other schools. The school would be a credit to the Government and it would be very convenient for the Department to have its Indian schools near Edmonton.

We therefore ask you dear Mr. Stewart to give the question of buying the school of St. Albert your earnest and early consideration and if you think favorably of it we shall convince the Sisters that you can only do justice to them in following the same policies for St. Albert as any place else. It may save your Department the expense of building a school at Robbema, by transferring the Indians to this institution.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) A. Jan, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Graham:

ST. ALBERT R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I beg to report that I visited this school on February 5th, and made a complete inspection of the building and visited the classrooms. I have reported very fully on this building in previous reports. It is a very fine building and provides accommodation for 250 boarders. Space is reserved for 100 Indian children. There were 96 present on the day of my visit. It is managed by the Order of Grey Nuns, and there are usually about 35 Sisters in residence. I was informed by the Sister Superior that they would very gladly dispense with the white boarders and utilize their whole space for the accommodation of Indian children if they could get the required number. The school building is in excellent condition and is always kept immaculately clean. The children also presented a healthy and cleanly appearance.

In addition to the classroom work, the boys assist in the farm work and feeding of cattle, and they also do the milking. The girls are taught butter-making, bread-making, general domestic work, and sewing. I took up the question of giving the girls practice at milking cows and was told that they had made an attempt to have the girls milk the cows, but they found that the cows did not take kindly to them, and that they gave a better flow when milked by the same person regularly.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
ST. ALBERT R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

This is a well known fact, but I suggested that they set aside a few of their inferior cows, if they had any, for the girls to practice on.

FARM

There is a large farm operated in connection with this school. Last season 150 acres of wheat yielded an average of 17 bus. per acre; 100 acres of oats averaged 45 bus. per acre; 45 acres of barley averaged 40 bus. per acre, which is a very good out-turn for last season. They had 10 acres of potatoes which yielded 1,500 bushels. They also have a large vegetable garden. Their stock consists of 123 cattle, 19 horses, and at the present time they have 14 brood sows. They raise between two and three hundred hogs each year. The farm supplies the institution with their meat, milk, butter and vegetable requirements. The boys, as I said before, assist in the farm work. There are six hired men kept in the winter and seven during the summer months. The Farming Instructor appears to be a very capable man. He received an agricultural college training. He informs me that it is their intention to feed all the grain to live stock that they grow on the farm.

They sustained a severe loss on September 28th, last, when their pigery burnt down. In addition to losing the building, they lost 30 hogs, which were ready for the market, 5 which were almost ready, 5 sows, a pure-bred boar valued at $75.00, and several young pigs. The intention, I believe, is to build a new hog house, which they expect will cost $6,000.00, and the Superior said that she would be very grateful if the Department could see their way clear to assist them towards defraying the cost of this building.

FARM

The larger boys assist with the farm work and in caring for the stock. They also do the milking.

The crops seeded last season included 20 ac wheat, 80 ac oats, 186 ac barley and 30 ac hay. They threshed 1000 bu of wheat, 3900 bu oats, 5100 bu barley all of good quality. Only about one half of the oat crop was threshed. The hay land produced about 60 tons of hay mostly timothy.

The garden produced an ample supply of potatoes and vegetables for their requirements including 2500 bu of potatoes of exceptionally fine quality, 60 bu of carrots and other vegetables in proportion.

They have 150 hens which is all that their hen house will accommodate. The Sister in charge stated that she would like to have double that number of hens but they could not afford to build the necessary accommodation as yet.

30 brood sows are kept and they have at this time 94 other pigs a number of which are ready to be butchered.

They hope to raise 300 young pigs during the coming season. The raising of hogs provides a most important source of income and food supply for the institution.

A very fine piggery has been built since my last visit at a cost of $5093.00. The Department assisted with the cost to the extent of $2000.00. It provides a feed house with two stories and a cellar. The size of this is 18'x 27'. Attached to this are two wings which provide 10 pens in each. This building is well ventilated, dry and comfortable. It is the most convenient hog house I have seen but I am of the opinion that it cost more than it should have done. I am of the opinion that this building could be duplicated for one half what it cost.

They have 139 cattle including two pure bred bulls and 46 milch cows. They milk between thirty and thirty five cows regularly throughout the year.

Their cow barn is old cramped and out of date having been built about twenty five years ago. A modern barn with plenty of room and air space as well as good drainage would add greatly to the comfort of the cows as well as promoting cleanliness in milking time.

The same remarks apply to the horse barn which has no drainage and is in a badly shaken condition. It would add to the appearance of this institution if the old outbuildings were torn down and replaced with buildings set farther away from the school in an orderly formation. They are now scattered all over the place and have anything but an attractive look.
Inspector Marison's Report on Schools Edmonton Agency

Dear Mr Graham,

I beg to submit the following report on the two residential schools in the Edmonton Agency.

St Albert Residential School (Roman Catholic)

This school is under the management of the Grey Nuns with the Rev' Sister Proulx in charge as Superior. She has an adequate staff of Sisters including three teachers, a seamstress, cook and boys and girls supervisors.

The heating, lighting and laundry equipment is in charge of a competent engineer and the farm and general outside work is in charge of Mr Fontaine who is a graduate of an Agricultural College.

School Building

The main building has three storeys and a basement. It is a spacious brick building with high ceilings, good ventilation and is provided with easy accessible fire escapes on each floor. Fire protection is provided by means of stand pipes with hose connections on each floor as well as chemical fire extinguishers which are conveniently placed.

I examined this equipment and found it in good condition. The pupils have been given two lessons in fire drill by a fire inspector from Edmonton and I was informed that they will be given regular fire drill practice from now on.

An ample supply of good soft water is obtained from a well under the building at a depth of 157 feet. The pump is operated by a steam engine and they have no difficulty in keeping up the supply and pressure.

I made a complete inspection of the whole building and found it well kept throughout. The dormitories provide ample air space and are provided with comfortable beds with homemade wool mattresses and are provided with an ample supply of bed clothes.

There are three bright class rooms with a teacher for each. 104 Indian pupils are enrolled; 46 boys and 57 girls.

The teacher in the senior room holds a 2nd class certificate for the Province of Alberta. The teachers in the intermediate and junior rooms have not had Normal school training. I find that the children are making good progress in acquiring a knowledge of the English language.

The girls assist in the kitchen and in the general housework of the institution and are given instruction in cooking, baking, the making of butter etc; practically all the clothing for both the boys and the girls is made by the girls under the supervision of an experienced seamstress. They are also taught knitting. The provision of wool balaclava caps was much appreciated. These are unravelled and the wool is utilized in making stockings. They have a knitting machine of an obsolete type which they purchased 45 years ago and they now find it impossible to get repairs for it.

The seamstress expressed a wish that a new machine be provided. I would be glad to see her get it as I think that the work which she is doing deserves encouragement.

Rooms have been assigned and equipped as an infirmary for the sick. It was noted that only common kitchen chairs were provided and the Sister in charge expressed a wish that a Morris chair be supplied.

The health of the pupils is very good at present and they presented a clean and well nourished appearance. Plenty of milk is supplied and wholesome meals provided.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina - Sask;

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report of an inspection made at the schools in the Edmonton Agency by Mr. Murison.

The situation at both the St. Albert and the Edmonton Residential Schools seems to be quite satisfactory, and the equipment is reported to be in good condition. The training that the children are receiving seems to be carried on in accordance with the Department's regulations, excepting that the milking is done by the boys, which, of course, is absolutely wrong. There has been a good deal said on this subject recently. We are trying to assist in the building up of the health of the Indians by making the girls who attend our boarding schools competent to carry on and care for their homes in a proper manner when they return to their reserves, and if they know little or nothing about milking they are going back under a great handicap, because any milking of cows that is done on an Indian reserve is done by the women, and for this reason I think the Department should insist on the milking at all schools being done by the girls.

I note that the seamstress at the St. Albert School expressed a wish to be supplied with a new sewing machine. I do not know why the school should not supply this themselves. My understanding was that such equipment was to be kept up by the school.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that I have received numerous complaints from the Indians of the Alexander, Alexis, Smoh and Michel Reserves regarding the treatment of the children attending the St. Albert Indian Residential School. On November 16th, at the request of the Chief and Councillor of the Michel Band, I met several of the parents of children attending this school for the purpose of investigating the complaints; we met at the St. Albert School and the meeting was attended by the Rev. Sister Superior, Principal of the School. The following complaints were made.

Alex Callihoo complained that the Sisters spoke French to the children and that the children could not understand and were then punished because they did not do what they were told. The Rev. Sister Superior stated that this was not correct as it was very seldom that any of the children were addressed in French, but that the Sisters when alone did converse with each other in French. He also stated that the children were not taught what they wanted to learn; I explained to him that the children were taught the regular studies as laid down by the Department and that it would be impossible for every child to be taught just what he fancied.

Mrs Courterille complained that the children were not allowed to go to the toilet after they had gone to bed. At my request the Sister in charge of the girls' dormitory was brought to the room and I asked her if the children were allowed to go to the lavatory during the night after they had retired, she stated that at no time during the night or day were the children refused this permission. Mrs Courterille then asked that her two girls be brought in and questioned, this was done. Both girls were questioned and stated that on more than one occasion one or the other had got out of bed for the purpose of going to the toilet and before they could get to the door the Sister had asked them where they were going and when told had ordered them back to bed. The Sister denied this and also the Rev. Sister Superior stated that such a thing had never happened in the school to her knowledge. I then dismissed the two girls and after they had left the room several of the parents who were present stated that the children were all afraid to speak as they would get a whipping after I had left the school. Mrs Courterille also complained that the fish served to the children had sugar sprinkled on it and the children could not eat it, the Sister in charge of the girls' dining room stated that if there was sugar on the fish at any time it must have been spilt out of the sugar basin accidently by some of the children.

M. Christiansen, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate,
Calgary, Alta.
Mrs Sam Callihoo complained that the Sisters in the big boys' room did not speak any English and that the boys were punished because they did not do what they were told, she states that this is not fair as the children do not understand French. The Rev. Sister Superior stated that the Sister in charge of this room was not Sisters sent to her by the Rev. Mother Superior and was allotted by the Rev. Mother Superior to this particular position, but stated that she would endeavour to have a Sister placed in this room who spoke English. Mrs Callihoo also complained that there was too much Religious teaching at the school and that the children had one hour prayers before school and that they were at prayers three and four times a day, she asked that more time be given to the regular educational studies.

Leo Breland complained that the children did not receive sufficient food and also complained regarding too much Religious teaching.

Simon Breland complained regarding the food served to the children and stated that they did not always get enough to eat and that on some occasions they had been given sour potatoes to eat; he also complained that the children were whipped too much. He stated that one boy had been whipped until his hands bled. I made inquiries into this case, the Rev. Sister Superior informed me that when this boy was being whipped on the seat that he had put his hand back behind him and the strap caught him on the hand sideways.

I have also received several complaints of a similar nature from the other Bands but chiefly about the food, thinking there must be some truth regarding the food served at the school. I made a surprise visit to the school at the noon hour yesterday, I went through all the dining rooms both girls' and boys' while they were at dinner and inspected the food. The children were having for their dinner, soup, shepherd's pie, this being made with the potatoes cooked on top of the meat, tapioca pudding, bread and butter and tea, there was plenty of food in each dining room and was well served by a Sister in each room. I tasted the meat pie and it was very good. I questioned all the children in each room and asked them if they were getting enough to eat every day and if the food was good, in each case the children all replied "yes".

After dinner the big boys asked if they could see me their request was brought to me by their master, I then went back to the boys' room and was informed by three of the big boys that they were called every morning between 4:30 A.M. and 4:45 A.M. to get up to go out to milk the cows, they stated that they did not mind the milking but they thought it was too early to be called up out of bed every morning. The Rev. Sister Superior who was present at the time, stated that this was not correct as she had given instructions a year ago that the boys were not to be called until 6 A.M. to get up to milk. I again questioned the boys and they insisted that this was the time they were called, they also asked that they be given turns to do the different work and not kept at one job for three or four months at a time, after the boys had left I went with the Rev. Sister Superior to the hired men's quarters and interviewed one of the men who assists with the milking; I asked him what time they started to milk in the mornings, he stated that they commenced to milk at 5 A.M. every morning; he also stated that the boys arrived at the barn about the time they had one cow nearly milked.
the boys being a little late as they were given coffee and toast before they went to the barn. In my opinion 4:30 A.M. is too early for these young boys to be called up out of bed every morning and I have asked the Rev. Sister Superior if she will arrange for the boys who are milking to be called at 5:45 A.M. instead of 4:30 A.M. so that the boys can get to the barn by 6 A.M., even this is early for these young lads.

There is no question in my mind that there is a certain amount of truth in the complaints made by the parents regarding the treatment of the children, but just at the moment I am unable to locate just where the trouble is; however, there has been some changes made at the school since the summer holidays, the boys have a new master, there is a new cook and a new Sister in charge of the big girls. I am of the opinion that the Rev. Sister Superior became aware that something was wrong and removed those who were responsible for the trouble. I think that with these changes that the children will be treated better and we will not have so many complaints in the future.

In conclusion Sir, I do not think the matter is serious enough for you to make a special trip to Edmonton to investigate these complaints, but I would ask that on your next visit to Edmonton that you would spare the time to go to the school with me to interview the Rev. Sister Superior regarding the complaints.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G.C. Laight,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

RE: LOTTIE BRELAND.

I wish to submit the following information regarding the accident which happened to Lottie Breland in December 1938.

It was on Monday morning, December 12, around 8 o'clock, that Lottie was sent with another young girl, Louise Ward, to help the laundress, Sister Xaverine, to pass the clothes through the mangle.

After assigning each girl her task, Louise feeding the mangle and Lottie receiving the dried clothes at the table of the mangle, the Sister went some ten feet behind them to prepare the indigo for the day's washing.

No more than ten minute had elapsed when the Sister heard a little cry upon which she turned towards the mangle but, very quiet and calm, neither of the girls called her. However she had scarcely turned her back again when she heard a scream. Instinctively she ran to the mangle, seized the lever, stopped the machine and loosened the rollers. This was the work of a second. Immediately she called the engineer, Mr. J. W. Meloche, from the adjoining room, who was already on his way to the laundry having been roused by the girl's scream. He at once turned back the mangle in the opposite direction and the hand was freed.

The laundress brought Lottie directly to the dispensary where Sister Quenneville, R.N., gave her the first treatments while Dr. R. Fairier was called by phone. When the girl reached the dispensary her right
hand was flattened and white but not otherwise deformed. A very thick picric ointment dressing was applied until the arrival of the Doctor some twenty minutes later. The hand was then uncovered; the fingers were examined; they showed no sign of fracture and moved naturally and without great pain. The dressing was made over, the fingers being wrapped separately.

On the Doctor's advice, your authorization, Mr. Laight, was asked to transfer the patient to the General Hospital; and according to your instructions, she was taken there at once.

Such are the details relating to Lettie Breland's case which I respectfully submit.

Yours very truly,

Sister V.M. Corriveau, principal.

Dear Sisters:

Re: Lottie Breland, by her father Leon Breland

Lottie Breland, around about Christmas, 1938, was put to work in the ironing department of your Institution by Sister Hoode.

Whilst alone operating a mangle, her hand was caught therein and every bone broken and otherwise burned. She is deformed for life and shall not be able to use that hand at any time. It is, in fact, likely to cause her further trouble, since she has no control over the fingers thereof. The Doctor has suggested amputation of the whole hand. That possibly might make it better for her since an artificial hand could be used to some advantage, whereas it is her hand can not be used without pain and danger of being subjected to further injury.

The child was at your Convent for tuition and on the assumption that it is reasonable to put a child to work in your institution, your duty is to give careful supervision and see that no harm comes to any child, even though she may be only an indian child.

A settlement of this matter will avoid the issuance of an action in damages against your institution, which we shall take as soon as vacation of the Court is over, by September. I hope in the meantime you will see that your own solicitors get in touch with me so as to effect settlement and avoid unnecessary costs.

Yours truly,

H. A. MACKIE, K.C.

Dear Mr. Mackie:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 18, in which you seek information with respect to the Indian pupils enrolled at the above institution.

The education of Indian children and the responsibility of the Government therefor is covered in a general way in section 10 - subsections 1 and 2 - of the Indian Act.

There are at this date 16,297 children enrolled at Indian day and residential schools throughout the Dominion. Of these, 9,040 are enrolled at Indian residential schools. At these residential schools the provincial curriculum, with certain modifications, has been adopted in each case. It has always been the policy of the Department to make provision at these schools whereby approximately half of the day is spent in regular classroom work and half in what one might term vocational or semi-vocational instruction: elementary agriculture, milking, the care of live stock, the cultivation of gardens, etc., in the case of boys, and in the case of girls, elementary domestic science, dressmaking, crochet work, fruit canning and preserving, cooking -

cooking, etc. The officials of the Training Division inform me that there is a constant demand from Indian parents for an extension of vocational instruction and still further curtailment of academic studies. It is my personal opinion that the present program is reasonably well balanced and adapted to the peculiar needs of the Indian pupil. Experience in this and other countries has taught educationists that it would be very unwise to take the average Indian pupil from life as it is lived on the reserve and confine him for lengthy periods during each day in the ordinary classroom.

Our Indian residential schools are inspected regularly by the provincial inspectors, who send forward their reports to the Department. The public school inspector, in his last report on the St. Albert school, states:

"Carefully planned lessons, with a good wealth of illustration, are provided at this school. Sound methods of instruction are very much in evidence. Grades 5, 6 and 7 receive classroom instruction during half of the teaching day on an alternate basis. The remainder of the pupils enrolled are taught during the whole of the day. The pupils are tidy in dress and appearance, well behaved and appear to be very happy in their school environment. Their application to study is well sustained. I am fully convinced that the classes know much more than they show to the supervising inspector under direct questioning. Very good exhibits of art work and writing were observed."

Summary of Inspector Scott's report on Youville Indian Residential School, November 22, 1930.

Intensive reading and language training appears essential in this school. In lesson preparation the encouragement of oral response should be a definite aim. The preparation of any materials that will tend to encourage spontaneous oral response will serve good purpose. Written work required exacting checking and follow-up discussions, and as far as possible a spirit of self criticism should be developed.

In junior grade reading teaching methods should aim for improved recognition span and better phrasing. The voice tone should improve throughout.

The classroom libraries are fairly good and accordingly some further effort may be made to encourage pupil research and oral reports in Social studies, Science and Health.

Training in the fundamental processes in Arithmetic was satisfactory.

There are many pupils who are age-retards for reasons which may be uncontrollable. Especially is this noticeable in grades 4 and 5. Approved remedial exercises should be planned to assist these pupils with their difficulties that they may progress reasonably before they become of age to leave the school.

Grades 6, 7 and 8 and the larger pupils in grades 4 and 5 receive academic training for a half day only each day. The other half day is utilized in the case of the boys for farm training and a certain limited amount of woodwork training. The girls are taught to sew or to keep house through kitchen and household duties. As result the academic training in these grades is based in the skill subjects largely.

Sewing for -
Sewing for the girls receives considerable attention. The room for manual training for the boys is too small and is poorly equipped. A better equipped room with some skilled instruction in woodwork, metal work and simple electrical work should prove beneficial for the boys.

The playground equipment is not extensive. A skating rink is provided for skating and hockey. Physical training is confined to that done in the classroom.

Singing receives due attention throughout.

Many of the pupils have limited background of general information and the process of learning is quite labored. Their powers of retention appear faulty. They require teachers who have had training in remedial teaching as it would require skilful teaching to meet their difficulties and needs effectively. Although the present teachers possess creditable aptitude for teaching I feel that better results would be achieved by teachers who had specialized training.

Under the supervision of Sister Corriveau the management of the school is orderly and systematic. The children are polite and show due respect to their teachers and to visitors. They pass back and forth to the classrooms in a very orderly manner. All rooms throughout the building appear neat and clean. The children are cleanly and comfortably dressed.

Dear Sir:

As the end of the year is fast approaching, we are looking over the expenses due for work already accomplished and in estimating the cost of the completion of the repairs we find that we are unable to meet our financial obligations.

This year, we have been making a great deal of alterations in fixing up the apartments of our Indian pupils so as to give them more healthful and pleasant surroundings, developing in them better habits of living for their own homes later on. A new installation of heating system had to be put in all the classrooms and dormitories, and all the children's quarters need painting very badly, work that hasn't been done for good many years on account of insufficient funds.

With your keen understanding of the financial expense needed for the maintenance of Institutions you will realize that at the present time the high cost of labor and materials adds to our difficulty.

We are now asking you, Mr. Phelan, to present our request to the Department that they come to our assistance to help us to defray our expenses.

Dear Mr. Faunt:

In preparing our budget for the next school year we are more than ever embarrassed to meet the necessary expenses.

The Department of Indian Affairs is well aware of the increased cost of living and wages, and that the cost of maintenance of buildings and equipment has practically doubled. They also know that we clothe, feed, shelter, instruct and give nursing care to all the Indian children placed in our institution. In order to give them the proper attention and care, we consider it impossible to carry on in the future at the present rate paid and I am sure that the Government will easily understand that it is inadequate.

We consider that we should receive not less than $25.00 per month per child, to meet the expense which we incur in furnishing the services above mentioned, and we trust that you will pass on to the authorities charged with the administration of Indian Affairs, our request, with a strong recommendation that the increase from $15.00 to $25.00 per child be authorised and made effective on September 1st. Further to the above named and copies of Edmonton Detachment report dated 17-9-47 which were forwarded to you on September 19th, Inspector George KEEP, Investigation Department, Canadian National Railways, Edmonton, Alberta., reports as follows:

QUOTE:

"Obstructions placed on Railway track rails in the vicinity of Mileage 9 and 11, Wabamun Sub., Can. Nt. Rlys. Between Bissell and Winterburn stations, just West of Edmonton.

On September 12th, 1947, at about 7 a.m., while freight train, extra west, engine No. 2166, Canadian National Railways, in charge of Conductor Butler and Loco. Engineer Franchuk, was proceeding west out of Calder Yards, North Edmonton, on reaching a point at mileage 9, ran into an obstruction on the rails in the form of used Railway track ties. A short distance farther at mileage 10, the train was brought to a standstill, it having been

....... noticed by the
Inspector of Indian Agencies,  
September 23rd, 1947.  
Calgary, Alberta.

noticed by the Engineer that two track rail angle bars were placed lengthways on the track rails, they having caught in the pony truck wheels on the engine and skidded them some distance.

The engineer's words in this connection were - "it is lucky our engine wasn't derailed and damage done". Obstructions of two inch boards and two other angle bars found farther on till mileage 11 was reached. The points mentioned are nine and 11 miles west of Edmonton C.N.R. station, and between the flag stations of Bissell and Winterburn.

My investigation disclosed the obstructions were placed on the Railway tracks by two Indians Boys named Albert Ward, age 13 and Percy William Papin, age 13, residing on Stony Plain Indian Reserve, about five miles west of Edmonton. The two boys, in the presence of Indian Agent E.A. Robertson and R.C.M.P. Police Constable B.R. Boyer and myself confessed to doing the mischief, saying they had run away from the Residential School at St. Albert on Friday morning early, September 12th, and it was while they were going to their homes the mischief was done.

The Railway Management and Board of Railway Commission take a very serious view of such happenings as above, and I would be pleased if it may be arranged to have the two boys appear before a Juvenile Court Judge for any action he cares to take, after hearing the circumstances."

As the actions of the two boys concerned may have resulted in a very serious accident it is thought that the boys should be taken before a Juvenile Judge for such action as he may see proper under the circumstances, as no doubt they were not aware of the possible results of placing obstructions on a railway.

Yours truly,

(C. Batch) INSPECTION OFFICER  
I.O. "K" DIVN. C.I.B.
Albert Ward & Percy Papin, (Treaty Indians), Winterburn, Alta., Juvenile Delinquent's Act - Assistance to C.H.R. Invest., Dept.

1. On the 17-9-47, Mr. George KEMP, of the C.H.R. Investigation Dept., called at this office, and stated that the above mentioned juveniles were suspected of placing three angle bars and three pieces of planking across the railroad tracks at or between miles nine and eleven. In view of this, Mr. KEMP requested assistance.

2. It was learned that these two juveniles aged thirteen, were Treaty Indians, belonging to the Knock Band, on the Winterburn Indian Reservation. They had been attending school at the St. Albert Mission, at St. Albert, Alta. Mr. KEMP and the writer interviewed the Sister in charge of the school, and the Sister in charge of the classroom where the juveniles had attended. They stated that the juveniles had left the school at approx. 2:00 p.m. of the 12-9-47, but without permission, and they were likely to return to the Reservation.

3. At 6:45 a.m. of the 12-9-47, it was alleged that the juveniles in question, had placed these obstructions on the tracks. Two or three people who lives nearby were interviewed, and it was found out that they had seen two juveniles coming from that direction of the tracks where the obstructions had been placed, but they could not positively identify them as such.

4. However, the writer and Mr. KEMP patrolled to the Reservation, and on contacting the Indian agent, succeeded the two juveniles. On being questioned, they quite readily admitted having placed the obstructions on the tracks, giving no reason for doing so.

5. There is no action being taken at this point by this office, as Mr. KEMP is contacting the Supt., of Child Welfare Dept., to be advised as to the proper action necessary in this case. File is being concluded at this point unless otherwise instructed.

Re: Youville Indian Residential School & Alexander's Indian Day School

Your File #110-1-1 (E)

Mr. Robertson Superintendent Edmonton Indian Agency has advised me that the Youville R. C. Convent will not accept any Indian children this year. This means that there will be no school for the children of the Alexis and Alexander Bands.

As you know, the attendance at Youville from the Alexis Band has always been poor; the parents do not co-operate and our superintendent finds it very difficult to locate the families during the Fall and Winter as they leave the reserve to camp wherever the father finds work; this may be in lumber camps or on trap lines. The closing of Youville is therefore not so serious, at the moment, insofar as the children of the Alexis Band are concerned.

However it is a serious matter for those from the Alexander Band; there are a number of children from this Band who would attend and their parents want them in school.

I suggest that the day school on this reserve be erected as quickly as possible. In order to accomplish this, it may be necessary to accept an offer to build it at a figure much higher than originally estimated or if need be, to accept an offer on a cost plus basis. You will no doubt have found it impossible to keep within your estimate for schools and still carry out your program owing to the steadily mounting costs. In this province up to the moment no contracts have been placed so far as I am aware and it is not because our superintendents have not tried to get bids. I know nothing has been done about the Good Fish Lake school, Saddle Lake agency. This school could be left for another year because the pupils can enter the Edmonton Residential School; in fact Mr. Staley needs this extra pupilage. In such an event could you not allow more money to complete the Alexander School?

A contracting firm might easily be located to erect this school and have it in readiness for occupancy by January 1949 if terms of the agreement were relaxed by the inclusion of an escape clause or as stated, if the contract were laid on a cost plus basis.

I see no other way to get these Indians into school. A few may get into provincial schools but the number would be negligible.

It is assumed that you have an overall appropriation allocated to this province; why not erect the most urgently needed schools even if the cost appears excessive? I have no other alternative to suggest in answer to your letter of August 13th, file 110-1-1 (E) just received.

It is suggested that these items be shipped to either the Edmonton Residential School or to the Ermineskin Residential School.
The school books, pencils, library books, etc., can be shipped to either the Michel or Stony Plain Schools. Some of the desks can also be stored for use in the projected Alexander School.

I would recommend that you have the two teachers of the Michel and Stony Plain Schools visit the Youville School and arrange for them to take over the text books, scribblers, etc., such as they require. Other stocks of text books left over can then be shipped to the Ermineskin school.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Youville Indian Residential School.

This school is a church-owned institution, operated by an Order of Sisters. It has always accepted old people and feeble-minded people requiring institutional care and assigned to it by the Provincial Department of Welfare.

For many years we have felt that the education of the children at this school was not being conducted in an atmosphere conducive to the best results.

We have, therefore, built two new day schools on the home reserves of the children who formerly attended this residential school. We will shortly submit to your office an Order-in-Council covering the building of a third day school.

We have, therefore, not been able to provide the minimum number of Indian children required for us to continue our contract with the Sisters operating this school. A letter has now been received from the Reverend Principal, reading as follows:

"In answer to your letter of July 23rd, we regret to inform you that due to the uncertainty of attendance of the small number of pupils available, and with present regulations of payment per capita for the pupils in attendance, it is inadvisable for us to accept your proposal.

"In severing our relations with your Department may we thank you for your kindness and courtesy in the past, with our best wishes for the future."

In view of this information, we have requested...
our Indian Superintendent to take an inventory of the departmentally-owned equipment at this school and it is our intention to transfer the desks, books, etc., to our other day and residential schools in the immediate vicinity. With the two day schools now erected and the one now planned, we will be able to offer adequate educational facilities for the Indian children who formerly attended this school. We would request your permission to advise our Chief Treasury Officer and others concerned that the Youville Residential School can be deleted from those institutions which are entitled to receive per capita grants and other benefits under the Education Vote of this Branch, effective September 1, 1948.

Director.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is determined by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the grant per pupil. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The average per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the rate of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils during the quarter, and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the rate of grant per pupil. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will there be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence. All pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils named on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for whom grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days resident of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return, and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added, and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days pupils attended school during quarter, obtained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. This Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is calculated by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE
