Sir,

I beg to inform you that I visited St. Albert, and the boarding school located at that point, on the 1st instant.

There are about 335 acres of land in connection with this institution and about 200 acres are farmed. This insures plenty of work for the advanced male pupils at farming.

The original main building is 4 stories and 35' x 180' in extent. A new brick structure about 50' x 100' and with 3 floors and a basement was erected a couple of years ago.

The girl pupils occupied the original building and the dormitories are located on the upper floor. There are 3 of these dormitories the air space and number of beds therein, are:

1. With air space of about 7230', cap. 14, beds 25
2. " 2640', " 5, " 9
3. " 3532', " 7, " 17

Totals: 26, " 51

This means that there are 25 too many occupying these dormitories, providing there were proper facilities to admit fresh and carry off foul air. No such appliances are provided.

When the reverend sisters learned that these dormitories would only accommodate 26 pupils they decided that

The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA.
it would be expedient to abandon the use of these rooms for sleeping use for grant earning pupils and to fit up dormitories in the new brick building for the girls. Grant earning boys have been using the new building from the time it was completed.

The basement of the new brick building contains the laundry, steam heating plant, a dormitory for those who work on the farm and other rooms.

The dormitory in the basement, referred to in the previous paragraph, is 19'x 40' and with a 10'9" ceiling. This will accommodate 17 persons and it was in use by 18.

As it was not definitely settled by the reverend sisters as to which rooms would be set apart for dormitories it was deemed prudent by me to defer a final inspection until this question is finally settled. The sisters now know the area of air space each pupil requires in the dormitories and in the class rooms and I presume they will be governed accordingly.

Three rooms on the 1st floor are reserved for classes, however, and these rooms are connected by wide doors. When these rooms are required for an assembly of pupils the doors will be opened and the three rooms form one room about 72' long and 21' wide. The distance from floor to ceiling is about 12'. The capacity of these 3 rooms is about 72 pupils.

A number of the rooms are connected to ventilating shafts which run up through the partition walls adjacent to the 6'10" corridors which extend the full length of the building and on every floor. Some of the rooms are not provided with these shafts, however. The location of the face plates in the walls does not appeal to me to be proper to carry off foul air. These open
face plates are about 10"x 14" and are set into the partition wall about 20" from the ceilings. I have suggested that these open face plates be taken out and connected to the ventilating shaft near to the floors in the various rooms and provide and place where the face plates now are controllable registers. My idea is that with such registers placed 20" from the ceiling that they can be closed during the cold weather and opened during the warm months. If so controlled they should retain the heat in the room during the cold weather and tend to suck off the warm air in the room during the warm months.

The open face grate placed near the floor, and connected to the air shaft, should carry away the foul air. Fresh pure air can be admitted into the various rooms by lowering the upper portion of the window sash.

This is a first class building and in my opinion it can be arranged to provide for about 70 pupils. There will be ample accommodation in the old building for hospital wards and when it is settled as to which rooms are to be used for such purposes the ventilation of the wards can be provided for.

This institution has accepted white children in the past. I was told that it has been decided to abandon the keeping and tuition of white children in the future.

The refectory for grant earning pupils is to be in the new brick building, too. The room selected is about 43'x 20'x 10'9" and the air space about 9245'.

Yours obediently,

Insp.

Madam,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Mr. Inspector Markle in which he states that the management of the St. Albert Boarding School has abandoned the intention of moving the Indian girls from the dormitories in the old building to those in the new and that consequently they do not intend to ask for an increased grant for the girls.

In this connection I beg to say that the Department regrets very much to learn of this decision. It will, however, be absolutely necessary to provide in some way more and better accommodation or else the number of children must be limited to about twenty-six. The dormitories in the old building have air space for only twenty-six pupils, whereas they are at present occupied by fifty-one. In order to obtain even the minimum grant under the new agreement with these schools sufficient dormitory space is necessary. It is provided in the letter which accompanied the agreement that if after due notice any school does not conform to the terms of the contract and of the memorandum of classification it will not be entitled to receive any grant. It will, therefore, be necessary for you to take into consideration either the reduction of the pupilage or the provision of suitable accommodation.

Sir,

re St. Albert Industrial School.

Without exceptions, St. Albert's Indian School is the best Institution I have visited so far, which I did on Saturday morning January the 24th.

In the morning I telephoned Mr. Race, Indian Agent for St. Albert, and he arranged to meet me at St. Albert's Industrial School in the afternoon. So I motored out, after picking up Dr. Giroux, to the Institution, where Mr. Race was waiting for me. The Sisters took us all through the buildings. They have eighty-three Indian children and a great many more who are not receiving support from the Government. The children are as contented and healthy a looking body I ever had the privilege of looking at. The place was spotlessly clean from top to bottom, good high ceilings, with a modern ventilation system, an infirmary at each end for the girls and boys respectively, and an isolation room for infectious diseases. The water is in abundance and pure in quality, being remarkably soft, a hot water heating plant, which is the best kind, and good drainage facilities. The only recommendation would be an outside laundry, as I do not like laundries in the main buildings, and besides it would give them added room.

They have had no epidemics, and the children according to the reports of Dr. Giroux and the Sisters, are singularly free from sickness.

O.I.Grain,
Medical Inspector, etc.

Honorable Sir:

Knowing all that you have done for our school in the past, and that our requests to the Indian Department have always been regarded favorably, I take the liberty to ask one more favor.

The pump which has been supplying the school with water for the past ten years was furnished by the Department; and until about two years ago it always gave satisfaction; but since then, one part is no sooner repaired than another part needs repairing. This is the Rider Pressure Engine (air pump) I have inquired as to the cost of installing another one, which is absolutely necessary; and it will cost between four and five hundred dollars.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, regarding the request of the Principal of the St. Albert Boarding School that the Department supply for the use of the school a steam jacket cooker, a boiler or steamer and a cream separator.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that equipment of this nature should be furnished by the school authorities. The cuts which you enclosed are returned herewith.

I would point out that in 1914, 60 desks were purchased and in August 1921, 12 more were furnished. This is a total of 92. At the request of the Rev. Principal of the St. Albert Boarding School I have obtained competitive prices of kitchen equipment from various firms handling these goods and beg to enclose abstract of same.

The McClary people quote prices on their own make of goods.

The Kelly Co. quote on the McClary catalogue but their prices are away too high for consideration.

Mr. Henderson quotes on the Prowse goods which are used by many of the largest hotels on the continent.

Mr. Greer has quoted prices on various makes taking as his guide the kind of article used by the majority of Hotels, Cafés and bakeries in the town and which by use have proved the most popular and serviceable.

The list of articles tendered on is the same as was submitted to the Department sometime ago by the Sisters but the Rev. Principal has since decided that she would dispense with the upright sectional cooker and in its place would like to have a potato peeler, meat chopper, sink, bread slicer and food rack. In this respect would say - if I may be permitted to offer an opinion- that this change is advisable but the potato peeler and bread slicer should be hand worked machines rather than power driven as the difference in cost is considerable and further more there are lots of boys and girls in the school who can do this work of operating the hand machine.

I am given to understand by the Rev. Principal that authority was promised for the purchase of these articles after competitive prices had been obtained; if so I would be glad to have instructions if the Department wish me to take further action in the matter.

I might add that in getting these prices and seeing the working of some of these machines at different places I came across a battery of urns in one of the cafés in town which could be bought very cheaply-it is in very good shape. There were also one or two other articles which could be bought worth the money which are not new but which have been in use only a short time.

The "Beatrice" separator is the kind in use by the Edmonton City Dairy and highly recommended by them.

I have gone into this matter very thoroughly to get all the information possible on the various makes of machines and the prices quoted are the lowest obtainable for first class goods and are all F.O.B. St. Albert.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Sept. 26, 1923.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing an abstract of tenders with reference to the purchase of kitchen equipment for the St. Albert Indian Residential School.

In reply I wish to state that the Department promised favourable consideration to requests for this type of equipment, not exceeding $500, and I should be pleased if you would communicate with the Sister Superior, with a view to ascertaining which articles to this value she would like the Department to purchase.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Geo. H. Race, Esq.,
